The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva is actually without such evil karma of the animal realm. By the power of great vows, he takes on these forms for the sake of sentient beings. This is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva not experiencing the evil karma in the present life or the next.
Moreover, good man!

In this Worthy Kalpa, there are also innumerable sentient beings born in the hungry ghost realm, some eating saliva, fat, flesh, pus, blood, feces, urine, snot, and spittle, with lifespans of innumerable hundreds of thousands of millions of years, never hearing the name of water, let alone seeing it with their eyes and being able to drink it.
If they see water from afar and go towards it with the intention to drink, when they arrive it turns into raging fire, pus, and blood;
or if it does not change, there are many people holding spears and halberds to guard and hold it back, not allowing them to approach;
or when heaven rains, it turns into fire upon reaching their bodies. This is called the retribution of evil karma.
Good son!

The Bodhisattva-mahÄsattva actually has no such fruits of evil karma, but in order to transform sentient beings and enable them to attain liberation, he vows to take on such a body. This is called the Bodhisattva-mahÄsattva not experiencing the fruits of evil karma in this life or the next.
Good son!
I was born into a butcher's family in the Worthy Eon, raised chickens, pigs, cows, and sheep, hunted, set traps and nets, and was a bandit in a chandÄla's house, committing robbery and theft.

The Bodhisattva actually has no such evil karma. In order to liberate sentient beings and enable them to attain liberation, he accepts such a body through the power of great vows. This is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva not experiencing the retribution for such evil karma in this life or the next.
Good man!

In this Worthy Eon, I was also born in border regions, often giving rise to greed, anger, and delusion, practicing non-dharma, not believing in the Three Jewels or the karmic retribution of future lives, and unable to respect parents, relatives, elders, and the elderly.
Good man!

At that time, the Bodhisattva actually had no such karma. In order to enable sentient beings to attain liberation, he was born there through the power of great vows. This is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva not experiencing the retribution for such evil karma in this life or the next.
Good man!

In this Worthy Eon, I again received a female body, an evil body, a greedy body, an angry body, an ignorant body, a jealous body, a stingy body, an illusory body, a deceitful body, and a body entangled in hindrances.
Good man!

At that time, the Bodhisattva also did not have such karma, but only for the sake of liberating sentient beings, he vowed to be born there by the power of great vows. This is called the Bodhisattva-mahÄsattva not experiencing these evil karmas in the present life or the next.
Good man!
In the Worthy Eon, I received the body of a eunuch, a body without genitals, a body with two genitals, and an indeterminate body.
Good man!

The Bodhisattva-mahÄsattva actually does not have such evil bodily karma, but in order to liberate sentient beings, he vows to be born there by the power of great vows. This is called the Bodhisattva-mahÄsattva not experiencing these evil karmas in the present life or the next.
Good man!

In the Bhadrakalpa, I again practiced the non-Buddhist path of Nirgrantha Jains. I believed in their teachings, thinking there is no giving, no sacrifice, no reward for giving and sacrifice, no good or bad karma, no retribution for good or bad karma, no present world or future world, no here or there, no sages, no transformed bodies, and no path or nirvana.
Good man!

The bodhisattva does not actually have such evil karma, but in order to liberate sentient beings, he accepts these wrong teachings through the power of his great vows. This is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva not experiencing the retribution for this evil karma in this life or the next.
Good man!
I remember in the past, I and Devadatta were both merchants. Each of us had five hundred merchants. For the sake of profit, we went to the great ocean to collect treasures.
Due to evil karma, we encountered a violent storm on the way, which blew our ship apart and all our companions died.
At that time, because of the karmic retribution of not killing and the conditions of long life, TÄ«rthika and I were blown by the wind and both reached the shore.
At that time, TÄ«rthika, greedy and stingy with his treasures, gave rise to great sorrow and suffering, and cried out in tears.
I then said:
TÄ«rthika!
Do not cry.
TÄ«rthika then said to me:
Listen carefully, listen carefully!
It is like a poor and destitute person who goes to a cemetery, grabs a corpse, and says:
I wish you would now give me the joy of death, and I will give you the life of poverty.
At that time, the corpse immediately sat up and said to the poor man:
Good man!
You can take the life of poverty and destitution yourself. I am now very happy with this joy of death. I really do not delight in your poverty and life.
But today, since I have no joy in death and am also poor, how can I help but cry?
I comforted him again, saying:
You should not worry. Now there are two pearls worth countless treasures. I will divide one and give it to you as a gift.
I then divided it and gave it to him, and said:
A person with life can obtain this treasure. If one has no life, who can obtain it?
At that time, I was exhausted and went to rest under a tree.
Devadatta, with his greedy mind burning, had an evil thought for the other pearl, stabbed my eyes, and robbed me of the pearl.
At that time, I was suffering from the wound and moaning. A woman came to me and asked:
Sir!
Why are you moaning like this?
I then explained the past events to her in detail.
The woman, after hearing it, asked me again:
What is your name?
I then replied:
My name is Real Speech.
The woman said:
How do we know that you are a person of real speech?
I then made a vow:
If I now have an evil mind towards Devadatta, my eyes will forever be blinded like this;
if I do not, I will regain my eyesight.
As soon as I spoke, my eyes returned to normal.
Good man!
This is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's explanation of the retribution in the present life.
Good man!
I recall that in the past, I was born in the brÄhman family in the city of PÅ«rvavideha in southern India.
At that time there was a king named KÄla, who was by nature violent and evil, arrogant and self-important, in the prime of youth and handsome, indulging in the five desires.
At that time, in order to deliver sentient beings, I was in silent meditation outside the city.
At that time, the king, in the spring when the trees were in full bloom, went out of the city with his retinue, palace ladies, and concubines to enjoy the five desires under the trees.
The concubines left the king to play and eventually came to where I was.
At that time, in order to cut off their greed, I expounded the Dharma for them.
Then the king came and saw me, and immediately gave rise to an evil mind, asking me:
Have you now attained the fruit of arhatship?
I said:
I have not attained it.
He said again:
Have you attained the fruit of non-returner?
I said:
I have not attained it.
He said again:
If you have not yet attained these two fruits, then you are still fully endowed with the afflictions of desire. How can you indulge in looking at my women?
I then replied:
Great King!
You should know that although I have not yet severed the fetters of greed, my inner mind is truly without attachment.'
The king said:

'Fool, there are ascetics in the world who ingest qi and eat fruits, yet they still lust after forms. How much more so for you, in the prime of your youth, not having severed greed and desire. How can you see forms and not be greedy?'
I said:
'Great King!
Seeing forms and not being attached is truly not due to ingesting qi or eating fruits. It is all because of fixing the mind on impermanence and impurity.'
The king said:
'If one slanders others out of contempt, how can one be said to be cultivating and upholding pure precepts?'
I said:
'Great King!
If there is jealousy, then there is slander.
I have no jealous mind, so how can it be said to be slander?'
The king said:
'Great Virtuous One!
What is called precepts?ğŸ”½'
'Great King!
Patience is called precepts.'
The king said:
'If patience is your precept, then I will cut off your ear. If you can endure it, I will know that you uphold the precepts.'
So he cut off my ear.
At that time, when my ear was cut off, my facial expression did not change.
Then the king's ministers, having seen this, admonished the king, saying:
'Such a great being should not be harmed.'
The king told his ministers:
'How do you know he is a great being?'
The ministers replied:
'We see that his facial expression does not change when he endures suffering.'
The king said again:
'I will test him further to see if his expression changes.'
So he cut off my nose, hands, and feet.
At that time, the Bodhisattva, having cultivated loving-kindness and compassion for immeasurable and boundless eons, felt pity for suffering beings;
Then the Four Heavenly Kings, their minds filled with anger, caused sand and gravel to rain down.
Seeing this, the king became greatly frightened and went to where I was. Kneeling for a long time, he said:
'Please have compassion and listen to my repentance.'
I said:
'Great King!
My mind is free from anger and also free from greed.'
The king said:
'Great Virtuous One!
How can you know that your mind is free from anger and resentment?'
I then made a vow:
'If I am truly free from anger and resentment, may my body be restored to its original state.'
Having made this vow, my body was immediately restored. This is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's teaching on the retribution in the present life.
Good man!
The retribution in the present life and the retribution in the next life of good karma, and also the retribution of unwholesome karma, are also like this.
When the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva attains anuttarÄ-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi, all karmas will attain retribution in the present life.
As for the retribution in the present life of unwholesome evil karma, it is like when a king does evil and the heavens send down evil rain.

It is also like a person who shows a hunter the location of a bear and a deer with precious fur, and their hands fall off. This is called the retribution of evil karma experienced in the present life.
Retribution in the next life means, for example, icchantikas, those who commit the four grave offenses and the five heinous crimes.
Retribution in a later life means, for example, a person who observes the precepts makes a deep vow, wishing to always obtain such a pure body of precepts in future lives.
If there are sentient beings with a lifespan of a hundred years, or eighty years, during that time they will become a wheel-turning sage king and teach and transform sentient beings.
Good man!
If karma is certain to bring retribution in the present life, it cannot bring retribution in the next life or a later life.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas cultivating the karma for the thirty-two marks of a great man cannot bring retribution in the present life.
If karma does not bring the three kinds of retribution, it is called indeterminate.
Good man!

If one says that all karmic actions definitely receive retribution, then one cannot cultivate the practice of purity, liberation, or nirvÄá¹‡a. One should know that such a person is not my disciple, but a follower of MÄra.
If one says that karmic actions have definite and indefinite [aspects], with the definite ones having present retribution, retribution in the next life, or retribution in a later life,
and the indefinite ones being experienced when conditions come together, but not experienced when conditions do not come together,
then for this reason there should be the practice of purity, liberation, and nirvÄá¹‡a. One should know that such a person is a true disciple of mine, not a follower of MÄra.
Good son!
All sentient beings have more indefinite karmic actions and fewer definite karmic actions. For this reason, there is a path to cultivate.
Because of cultivating the path, one can make heavy definite karmic actions to be experienced lightly, and indefinite karmic actions will not be experienced in this life.
Good son!
There are two kinds of people:

First, making certain karma into uncertain retribution, making present retribution into retribution in the next life, making light retribution into heavy retribution, and what should be experienced in the human realm into being experienced in hell.

Second, making uncertain karma into certain karma, what should be experienced in the next life is changed to be experienced in the present life, heavy retribution becomes light, and what should be experienced in hell is lightly experienced in the human realm.
These two people, one is foolish and the other wise. The wise one is made light, and the foolish one is made heavy.
Good man!
It is like two people who have committed crimes against the king. The one with many relatives has his crime lightened, while the one with few relatives has his light crime made heavier.

The foolish and the wise are also like this. The wise one has more good karma, so the heavy [karma] is experienced lightly, while the foolish one has less good karma, so the light [karma] is experienced heavily.
Good man!
It is like two people, one is fat and strong, the other is thin and weak. They both sink into deep mud, the fat and strong one can get out, but the weak one sinks.
Good man!

It is like two people who both ingest poison, one has the power of spells and agada, the other does not. The one who relies on spells and medicine, the poison cannot harm them, the one without spells and medicine, when they ingest it, they die immediately.
Good man!

It is like two people who both drink a lot of liquid, one has strong digestive heat, the other is weak. The one with strong digestive heat can digest it, the one with weak digestive heat will be harmed by it.
Good man!
It is like two people who are bound by the king, one has wisdom, the other is foolish. The wise one can escape, the foolish one has no chance of escape.
Good man!
It is like two people traveling together on a dangerous road, one has eyes, the other is blind. The one with eyes can pass through without trouble, the blind one falls into a deep pit.
Good man!

It is like two people drinking alcohol together, one eating a lot and the other eating little. The one who eats a lot can drink without harm, while the one who eats little will become ill from drinking.
Good man!
It is like two people together in a battle against an enemy army, one fully armored and the other naked. The one with armor can defeat the enemy, while the naked one cannot protect themselves.

There are also two people whose clothes are soiled with excrement. One immediately washes them, while the other ignores them. The one who washes them immediately will have clean clothes, while the soiled ones will only become dirtier with time.
There are also two people riding in a cart together, one with an axle and the other without. The one with an axle can go wherever they wish, while the one without an axle cannot move at all.

There are also two people traveling together on a long road, one with provisions and the other going empty-handed. The one with provisions will be able to pass through the dangers, but the one going empty-handed will not be able to get through.
Again, there are two people who are robbed by thieves, one has treasure and the other does not. The one with treasure has no worries in his mind, but the one without treasure is sorrowful.
Fools and wise people are also like this. Those with good treasure will experience heavy karma lightly;
Those without good treasure will experience light karma heavily.
Bodhisattva Siá¹ƒha-nÄda said:
World-Honored One!
As the Buddha has said, not all karmic actions will definitely bring about results, and not all sentient beings will definitely experience them.
World-Honored One!
How do sentient beings cause light retributions in the present to be experienced as heavy in hell?
How do they cause heavy retributions in hell to be experienced as light in the present life?
The Buddha said:
All sentient beings are generally of two kinds:
The first is the wise, and the second is the foolish.
If one is able to cultivate body, precepts, mind, and wisdom, this is called the wise;
If one is unable to cultivate body, precepts, mind, and wisdom, this is called the foolish.
What is meant by not cultivating the body?
If one is unable to restrain the five sense faculties, it is called not cultivating the body.
Not being able to uphold the seven kinds of pure precepts is called not cultivating precepts.
Because the mind is not disciplined, it is called not cultivating the mind.
Not cultivating the holy practices is called not cultivating wisdom.
Furthermore, not cultivating the body means not being able to fully possess the pure body of precepts.
Not cultivating precepts means accepting and keeping the eight kinds of impure things.
Not cultivating the mind means being unable to cultivate the three kinds of characteristics.
Not cultivating wisdom means not cultivating the holy life.

Furthermore, one who does not cultivate the body is unable to contemplate the body, unable to contemplate form and contemplate the characteristics of form, unable to contemplate the characteristics of the body, does not know the number of bodies, does not know that this body goes from here to there, gives rise to the notion of body in what is not a body, creates the notion of form in what is not form, and therefore becomes attached to one's own body and the number of bodies, which is called not cultivating the body.
One who does not cultivate precepts means if one receives inferior precepts, it is not called cultivating precepts.

Receiving and upholding extreme precepts, precepts for one's own benefit, precepts for one's own discipline, unable to universally bring peace and joy to sentient beings, not for the sake of upholding the unsurpassed true Dharma, for the sake of being reborn in the heavens to enjoy the five desires, is not called cultivating precepts.

One who does not cultivate the mind means if the mind is scattered and unable to be focused and guarded in one's own realm, one's own realm refers to the four establishments of mindfulness, while the realm of others refers to the five desires.
If one is unable to cultivate the four establishments of mindfulness, it is called not cultivating the mind.
In evil karma, not guarding the mind is called not cultivating wisdom.
Furthermore, one who does not cultivate the body cannot deeply contemplate that this body is impermanent, unstable, fragile, perishing moment by moment, and is the realm of Mara.
One who does not cultivate precepts cannot perfect the perfection of precepts.
One who does not cultivate the mind cannot perfect the perfection of meditation.
One who does not cultivate wisdom cannot perfect the perfection of wisdom.
Furthermore, one who does not cultivate the body is attached to the body of self and the body of what belongs to self, thinking that the body of self is permanent and unchanging.
One who does not cultivate precepts commits the ten evil deeds for the sake of one's own body.
One who does not cultivate the mind cannot concentrate the mind in evil karma.
One who does not cultivate wisdom, due to not concentrating the mind, cannot discern good and evil dharmas.
Furthermore, one who does not cultivate the body does not eliminate the view of self.
One who does not cultivate precepts does not eliminate attachment to precepts.
Those who do not cultivate the mind create the karma of greed and hatred and head towards hell.
Those who do not cultivate wisdom do not eliminate the deluded mind.
Furthermore, those who do not cultivate the body are unable to contemplate that although the body is without fault, it is always an enemy.
Good man!
It is like a man who has an enemy always chasing after him, looking for an opportunity to strike;
The wise, having realized this, fix their minds and carefully guard themselves. If they do not carefully guard themselves, they will be harmed.

All sentient beings' bodies are also like this. They should always nourish them with drinks, food, and proper care. If they do not carefully protect and watch over them, they will immediately disintegrate.
Good man!
It is like a Brahmin who serves the fire god, always offering incense, flowers, praise, worship, and service for a hundred years. If he touches it once, it will immediately burn his hand.
Although the fire receives such offerings, it never has a single thought of repaying the one who serves it.

The bodies of all sentient beings are also like this. Even if they are provided with good incense, flowers, necklaces, clothing, food, bedding, and medicine for many years, if they encounter internal and external evil conditions, they will immediately be destroyed and will not remember the kindness of providing clothing and food from the past.
Good man!
It is like a king who keeps four poisonous snakes in a box and entrusts someone to take care of them.
If one of these four snakes becomes angry, it can harm people.
This person is terrified and always seeks food and drink, guarding them in a timely manner.
The four great poisonous snakes of all sentient beings are also like this. If one of the great ones becomes angry, it can destroy the body.
Good man!
If a person has a chronic illness, they should wholeheartedly seek medical treatment. If they do not diligently seek help, they will certainly die without a doubt;
The bodies of all sentient beings are also like this. They should always concentrate their minds and not be negligent. If they are negligent, they will be destroyed.
Good man!
It is like a clay pot that cannot withstand wind, rain, beating, throwing, or pressing;
The bodies of all sentient beings are also like this. They cannot withstand hunger, thirst, cold, heat, wind, rain, beating, binding, or harsh scolding.
Good man!
It is like a boil that has not yet ripened. It should always be well protected, not allowing people to touch it. If someone touches it, it will cause great pain;
The bodies of all sentient beings are also like this.
Good man!
It is like a mule that becomes pregnant and harms its own body. The bodies of all sentient beings are also like this. If there is wind or cold inside, the body will be harmed.
Good man, it is like a banana tree that withers after bearing fruit;
The bodies of all sentient beings are also like this.
Good man!
It is also like a banana tree that has no solid core inside;
The bodies of all sentient beings are also like this.
Good sons!
Just as snakes, rats, and wolves always give rise to enmity towards each other,
the four great elements of sentient beings are also like this.
Good sons!
Just as the king of geese does not enjoy cemeteries,
bodhisattvas are also like this, not greedy for the body's cemetery.
Good sons!
Just as the seven generations of a caá¹‡á¸Äla family are not abandoned, and therefore they are despised by others,
the seeds of this body are also like this. The seeds of semen and blood are ultimately impure, and because of their impurity, they are despised and reprimanded by buddhas and bodhisattvas.
Good sons!

This body is not like the Mount Malaya that produces sandalwood, nor can it produce utpala flowers, pundarika flowers, champak flowers, mallika flowers, or vashika flowers. From the nine orifices, pus, blood, and impurities constantly flow out, and the place of birth is foul-smelling and ugly, always sharing the same place with various insects.
Good man!
It is like the world, although there are the best and purest gardens and forests, when a corpse arrives in the middle, it becomes impure, and everyone abandons it, not giving rise to attachment.
The form realm is also like this. Although it is pure and wonderful, because there is a body, the buddhas and bodhisattvas all abandon it.
Good man!
If there are those who are unable to contemplate in this way, they are called those who do not cultivate the body and do not cultivate precepts.
Good man!

If one is unable to contemplate that precepts are the ladder for all wholesome dharmas, and also the root of all wholesome dharmas, like the earth which is the root from which all trees and plants grow;
that they are the leader of all wholesome roots, like a merchant leader guiding a group of merchants;
that precepts are the supreme banner of all wholesome dharmas, like the supreme banner erected by the Heavenly Emperor;
that precepts can permanently sever all evil karma and the three evil destinies, and can cure serious illnesses like a medicinal tree;

that precepts are provisions for the perilous path of birth and death, that precepts are armor and weapons for destroying the enemy of afflictions, that precepts are a good mantra for eliminating the poisonous snake of afflictions, that precepts are a bridge for crossing over the practice of evil karma.
If there are those who are unable to contemplate in this way, they are said to be not cultivating precepts.
Those who do not cultivate the mind are unable to contemplate the mind, which is fickle, agitated, difficult to grasp and tame, running wild like a great vicious elephant;
fleeting moment by moment, like a flash of lightning;
Restless and unstayed, like a monkey, like an illusion or a mirage, it is the root of all evil.
The five desires are difficult to satisfy, like fire receiving firewood;
Also like the great ocean, swallowing and receiving all flowing waters;
Like Mount Mandara, with abundant grasses and trees;
Unable to contemplate the falsity of birth and death, indulging in desires leads to suffering, like a fish swallowing a hook;
Always leading the way, with karma following along, like a mother leading her children;
Attached to the five desires, not delighting in nirvana, like a camel eating honey until death;
Not caring about withered grass, deeply attached to present pleasures, not considering future faults, like a cow greedily eating sprouts, not fearing the beating.
Roaming through the twenty-five existences, like a swift wind blowing cotton wool;
Seeking what should not be sought, seeking without being content, like a foolish person seeking fire without heat, always delighting in birth and death, not delighting in liberation;
Like a worm that enjoys the neem tree, deludedly attached to the foul stench of birth and death;ğŸ”½Like a prisoner who enjoys the warden's daughter;
Also like a pig in a latrine, enjoying the filth.
If there are those who cannot contemplate in this way, it is called not cultivating the mind.

Those who do not cultivate wisdom do not contemplate that wisdom has great power, like a garuá¸a that can destroy evil karma, destroy the darkness of ignorance, like sunlight, and uproot the aggregates like a flood sweeping away objects;
Burning away wrong views like a raging fire.
Wisdom is the root of all wholesome dharmas, the seed of the mother of buddhas and bodhisattvas.
If there are those who cannot contemplate in this way, it is not called cultivating wisdom.
Good man!

In the ultimate truth, if one sees the body, characteristics of the body, causes of the body, fruits of the body, aggregates of the body, oneness of the body, duality of the body, this body, that body, cessation of the body, equality of the body, cultivation of the body, one who cultivates, if there is such seeing, it is called not cultivating the body.

Good son!ğŸ”½If one sees precepts, characteristics of precepts, causes of precepts, fruits of precepts, higher precepts, lower precepts, aggregates of precepts, oneness of precepts, duality of precepts, these precepts, those precepts, cessation of precepts, equality of precepts, cultivation of precepts, one who cultivates, the perfection of precepts, if there is such seeing, it is called not cultivating precepts.

If one sees the mind, characteristics of the mind, causes of the mind, fruits of the mind, aggregates of the mind, the mind and mental factors, oneness of the mind, duality of the mind, this mind, that mind, cessation of the mind, equality of the mind, cultivation of the mind, one who cultivates, higher, middling, and lower minds, wholesome minds, unwholesome minds, if there is such seeing, it is called not cultivating the mind.

Good man, if one sees wisdom, the characteristics of wisdom, the causes of wisdom, the fruits of wisdom, the accumulation of wisdom, the oneness of wisdom, the duality of wisdom, this wisdom, that wisdom, the cessation of wisdom, the equality of wisdom, the superior, middling, and inferior wisdom, dull wisdom, sharp wisdom, the cultivation of wisdom, the cultivator, if there is such a view, it is called not cultivating wisdom.

Good man, if there are those who do not cultivate the body, precepts, mind, and wisdom, such people will receive great evil retribution for even minor evil deeds. Out of fear, they always think like this:
'I belong to hell, and I am practicing the conduct of hell.'
Although they hear the wise ones speaking of the suffering of hell, they always think like this:
'Just as iron strikes iron, stone strikes stone, wood strikes wood, and fire insects enjoy fire, the body of hell is similar to hell.
If it is similar to hell, what is there to suffer?'
It is like a fly that is stuck by saliva and cannot escape.
This person is also like this, unable to extricate themselves from minor offenses.

The mind is initially without remorse, unable to cultivate goodness, and conceals faults and flaws. Although they may have all kinds of good karma from the past, it is all defiled by this offense. The person's present light retribution is transformed into the extremely grave evil fruits of hell.
Good man!
It is like a small amount of water in which one sheng of salt is dissolved, its taste is salty and bitter, difficult to drink. The person's karmic offenses are also like this.
Good man!
It is like a person who owes another one coin, unable to repay it, their body is bound and they suffer many hardships. The person's karmic offenses are also like this.
Bodhisattva Siá¹ƒha-ghosa said:
World-Honored One!
Why does this person cause the present light retribution to transform into the suffering of hell?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
If all sentient beings possess five things, they can transform the light retribution of the present into the experience of hell.
What are the five?

First, because of ignorance; second, because of the paucity of wholesome roots; third, because of the profundity and heaviness of evil karma; fourth, because of not repenting; fifth, because of not cultivating the original wholesome karma.
There are also five things:

First, because of cultivating evil karma; second, because of lacking the wealth of precepts; third, because of being far from all wholesome roots; fourth, because of not cultivating the precepts and wisdom of the body and mind; fifth, because of associating with evil friends.
Good man!
Therefore, it can cause the light retribution of the present world to be heavily experienced in hell.
The Lion's Roar said:
World-Honored One!
What kind of person can transform the retribution of hell and experience it lightly in the present world?
Good man!

If one cultivates body, precepts, mind, and wisdom as explained above, and is able to contemplate all dharmas as being the same as empty space, not seeing wisdom, not seeing the wise, not seeing foolishness, not seeing the foolish, not seeing cultivation and the cultivator, this is called a wise one.
Such a person is able to cultivate body, precepts, mind, and wisdom. This person is able to cause the retribution of hell to be experienced lightly in the present life.
If such a person were to create extremely grave evil karma, through contemplation and insight, he would be able to make it light. He would think like this:
Although my karma is grave, it is not as good as good karma.
It is like cotton flowers, even a hundred pounds of them, still cannot match a single ounce of genuine gold.
It is like throwing a pint of salt into the Ganges River, the water has no salty taste and the drinker does not notice it.
